table-wrap.anchoringText: The static related uncertainty is mainly resulted from the measurement error and lack of information between the wells. The main uncertainty parameters and their respective ranges were identified, selected, and analyzed using Experimental Design to generate a tornado plot which enables the selection of the most influential parameters on the objective function. The main static uncertainties identified from data analysis and interpretations are listed in the Table 1. The applied workflow to capture full spectrum of the static uncertainty is depicted in Figure 2.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Base case parameters and ranges for static uncertainties

formatted-caption.caption-text: Base case parameters and ranges for static uncertainties

tr.td: Based on logs observation, MDT & Prod. Test

Based on available PVT results. 0.89 and 1.11 are the deviation seen from data points

tr.td: Base case Nw & No increased/decreased for low and high case based on Gate-5 uncertainties and results

td.b: Very low communication across dense layer

tr.td: Dense layer communication between BII porous and BIII Upper. Sensitivities compatible with the history match of the Base case
High vertical transmissibility’s has positive impact in recovering higher volumes compare to the base case. The variation has been within the available SCAL data

table-wrap.anchoringText: The prediction profiles obtained with the simulation model had to be extrapolated to 2150 prior to defining economic cutoffs (for reserves category). The Recovery Factors obtained in the different development scenarios (running the Base Case model with the Low, Base and High parameters assumptions) are given in the following Table 3.
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Recovery factors obtained with the Low, Base, High sensitivities on Base case model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Recovery factors obtained with the Low, Base, High sensitivities on Base case model
